Jiangxi 343100 China dJiangxi Xintai Functional Materials Technology Co., Ltd., Jiangxi 343100, China ⁎ Corresponding author. The position of the catalyst in a plasma reactor has an important effect on performance of plasma driven catalytic reaction. An operando diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) and mass spectrometry (MS) has been used to investigate CO oxidation on MnO2 catalyst in in-plasma catalysis (IPC) and post-plasma catalysis (PPC) configurations. It was found that the catalyst in IPC configuration has higher CO conversion and CO2 selectivity than that in PPC configuration. Operando DRIFTS-MS analysis showed that the IPC configuration generated more reactive oxygen species (MO) on the catalyst surface than the PPC configuration, where MO, M2+-O2 2–, and M + O2 – are important reactive species promoting CO oxidation to monodentate carbonate that is easy to gasify to gaseous CO2. The physical adsorbed O3 on the catalyst in PPC configuration converts to M2+-O2 2– which combines with CO to form bidentate carbonates that is difficult to gasify to gaseous CO2. The mechanisms of CO oxidation on the catalyst in IPC and PPC configurations are discussed. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Operando DRIFTS-MS In-/post-plasma catalysis CO oxidation Surface oxygen species Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Non-thermal plasma (NTP) catalysis technologies have great advantages in VOCs degradation. However, the formation of CO by-product is a problem [1,2]. CO is a colorless, odorless, and toxic for human health [3,4]. Patients after breathing CO gas have symptoms such as headache, dizziness, and insomnia, which can cause one to suffocate and die [5]. There are studies focusing on the complete oxidation of CO using plasma and catalysis. Dong et al. achieved efficient and stable CO oxidation on monolithic Mn3O4/TiO2; complete CO oxidation can be achieved at a temperature as low as 160 °C using conventional plasma electrolytic oxidation [6]. Zhang et al. prepared several Nb-doped CuOx/CeNbOx catalysts with different Ce/Nb molar ratios, and found the CuOx/Ce(0.9)Nb(0.1)Ox catalyst can catalyze the complete oxidation of CO using a plasma catalysis reactor at an energy density of about 600 J/L [7]. A NTP catalysis reactor has two configurations: in plasma catalysis (IPC) where the catalyst is installed in the discharge zone and post plasma catalysis (PPC) where the catalyst is placed downstream of the discharge zone. In IPC configuration, both long-life and short-life reactive species produced in the discharge zone have effects on the catalyst surface, but in PPC configuration only long-life reactive species such as ozone (O3) can reach the downstream-placed catalyst [8]. Compared with PPC configuration, the catalyst in IPC configuration can make both long-life and short-life reactive species function more effectively, thereby increasing the oxidation efficiency of CO [9,10]. Yu reported a comparison of IPC and PPC configurations for toluene plasma catalysis on Ag/ZSM-5 abatement [11], it was found that IPC had higher mineralization rates but lower energy consumption than PPC, indicating IPC has a higher CO2 production rate but a lower toluene conversion rate. Meanwhile, manganese-based catalysts have been widely used for CO reduction in plasma catalysis systems due to their excellent adsorption capacity and catalytic activity [12,13]. Shi et al. proposed a plasma-transition metal oxide catalytic system to achieve CO oxidation at room temperature and atmospheric pressure [14]. Peters et al. utilized dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) for the catalysis oxidation of n-butane. The results showed that 40% n-butane conversion and 73% CO2 selectivity could achieve at a specific energy density of 390 J/L and 140 ℃ [15]. Woldu et al. used Ar plasma to bombard the nanostructures on catalyst surface, they found that the activity and CO2 selectivity could be significantly enhanced [16]. However, the reaction processes of CO oxidation on catalyst surface are still not clear. An operando diffuse reflection infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (operando DRIFTS) is capable to identify reactive species for various reactions on the surface of the catalyst, even with a small DBD zone over the catalyst. Ji et al. used an in-situ DRIFTS to study O3 and O2 adsorption on the surfaces of CaO, ZnO, Al2O3, CuO, and Fe2O3 at room temperature, and found O3 –, O2 –, and O are intermediates related with O3 decomposition [17]. Li et al. prepared MnO2 with different phase structures for post-plasma catalytic systems degradation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs). The presence of amine and nitromethane functional groups were observed using Fourier transform infrared spectrometer [18]. Yao et al. used the combination of an in-suit DRIFTS with a mass spectrometer (MS) to observe the functional groups on the catalyst surface and the changes in MS signals of gaseous components during the catalytic oxidation of toluene on CeO2 [19]. Jia et al. sufficiently explored the adsorption and plasma-catalytic oxidation mechanism of toluene on CeO2 in IPC and PPC configurations [9]. Therefore, the operando DRIFTS is an indispensable characterization method for investigating the mechanism of plasma-catalysis reaction. Herein, we chose β-MnO2 as a model catalyst as it has a clean surface of less surface oxygen species than other types (α, γ, and δ) of MnO2 [20,21]. The performance of CO oxidation on β-MnO2 using a DBD reactor in IPC or PPC configuration is investigated. The CO oxidation on β-MnO2 is also characterized using an operando DRIFTS-MS to find the differences in CO oxidation mechanisms on β-MnO2 in IPC and PPC configurations. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst characterization Physicochemical properties of β-MnO2 (purity 99%, Aladdin, Shanghai, China) were characterized using via various techniques, such as X-ray Powder Diffraction (XRD), X-ray electron energy spectroscopy (XPS), and oxygen temperature programmed (O2-TPD). The detailed characterization procedures are provided in the Supplementary Materials Section. 2.2 Experimental setup Fig. 1 (a) shows an experimental setup for the investigation of CO oxidation using a DBD reactor with IPC configuration. A power supply (M10K-08, Suzhou Allftek, China) was used to supply voltage pulses to the DBD reactor to generate gas discharges in the gas space between stainless-steel electrode (connected with the high voltage terminal of the power supply) and stainless-steel foil (connected with the ground terminal of the power supply). A voltage probe (P6015A, Tektronix, USA) and current probe (CP8030H, Cybertek, China) were used to measure waveforms of discharge voltage and current using an oscilloscope (MDO3022, Tektronix, USA). A gas mixture containing 1 vol.%CO, 20 vol.%O2, and 79 vol.%Ar was supplied at a total gas flow rate of 150 mL/min to the inlet of the DBD reactor. A gas chromatograph (GC, GC3420A, Beijing Chromatograph, China) was used to measure CO and CO2 concentrations in the gas mixture from the gas mixer or the outlet of the DBD reactor. An ozone meter (BMOZ-200 L, Shengxin, China) was used for monitoring O3 concentration in the gas mixture from the outlet of the DBD reactor. Fig. 1(b) shows the geometry of the DBD reactor with PPC configuration. Fig. 2 (a) and 2(b) were used to explore the behaviors of functional groups on the catalyst surface and gas concentrations during CO oxidation on the catalyst in IPC and PPC configurations. A gas mixture containing 20 vol.%O2 and 80 vol.%Ar (without CO) or 1 vol.%CO, 20 vol.%O2, and 79 vol.%Ar (with CO) with a total gas flow rate of 38 mL/min was supplied to the inlet of a reaction chamber (HVC-DRP-5, Harrick, USA) installed in an operando DRIFTS-MS system (Nicolet IS50, Thermo Scientific, USA). The reaction chamber was equipped with a small quartz tube with a stainless-steel rod used to generate gas discharges over the catalyst (Fig. 2(a)). Fig. 2(b) simulated the catalyst in PPC configuration by feeding O3 gas (from a DBD reactor) to the reaction chamber. CO and CO2 concentrations were monitored using the MS (Tilon LC-D200M, Ametek, USA). Details in DRIFTS-MS-TPR operations are given in the Supplementary Materials Section. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization with XRD, O2-TPD, and XPS The X-ray diffractogram of β-MnO2 is shown in Fig. 3 (a). The diffractogram shows that the β-MnO2 catalyst is well indexed and consistent with the lattice constant of β-MnO2 (JCPDS 24–0735) [22,23]. The narrow peak width of β-MnO2 indicates that it has a high crystallinity. The TCD signals as a function of desorption temperature during O2-TPD experiment is shown in Fig. 3(b). O2 species desorbed below 300 °C are represented as catalyst surface active physical/chemosorption or active lattice oxygen species (Olow); those desorbed at 300–600 °C are represented as subsurface lattice oxygen (Omid); and body lattice oxygen (Ohigh) typically occurs above 600 °C [20]. Olow is more active than Omid or Ohigh during CO oxidation [24]. As shown in Fig. 3(b), only a small peak at 150 °C can be found, the β-MnO2 used in this study has very limited surface oxygen species. XPS spectra were obtained to determine the valence states of surface Mn and O atoms. Fig. 3(c) shows the Mn 2p3/2 spectrum of the β-MnO2 sample. Peaks at 643.4, 642.3 and 641.8 eV are attributed from Mn4+, Mn3+, and Mn2+, respectively [20,23]. Mn atoms in the low-lying states exhibit a weak Mn-O bond, indicating that the oxygen atoms bonding with Mn atoms are more likely to be released to participate in oxidation reaction. The valence states and their fractions of Mn are listed in Table 1 . When Mn4+ downshifts to Mn3+, oxygen vacancies can be created to balance the charge. It is obvious that surface Mn atoms on β-MnO2 are reducible or oxidable, and can generate oxygen vacancies which are important for oxidation reaction [25]. The XPS spectrum of O1s is shown in Fig. 3(d). The asymmetrical O1s spectrum is deconvolved into three peaks. The main species with a binding energy of 529.2 eV is assigned to lattice oxygen (O2–) (denoted as Olatt). The signal with a binding energy of 531.7 eV corresponds to the surface adsorbed low coordination oxygen (denoted as Oads) and the binding energy is 533.2 eV belongs to the hydroxyl‑like group (denoted as Oads O H) [26,27]. β-MnO2 has a higher fraction of Olatt and a lower fraction of Oads. Therefore, β-MnO2 can supply a clean surface of lower fraction Oads and is conducive to better studying the surface intermediates during CO oxidation. 3.2 CO oxidation in the DBD reactor CO conversion and CO2 selectivity in the DBD reactors with PPC and IPC configurations or in the DBD reactor without a catalyst (NTP alone) are shown in Fig. 4 (a, b). The energy density (ED) was changed by changing peak values of voltage pulses, where the waveforms of voltage and current are shown in Fig. S1. At 300 J/L, CO conversion has an order of 37% (IPC) >26% (PPC) > 15% (NTP), while CO2 selectivity is in the order of 99% (NTP) >93% (IPC) >82% (PPC). β-MnO2 catalyst can obviously promote CO conversion to CO2, but has lower CO2 selectivity than NTP alone. This finding suggested that CO oxidation products on β-MnO2 catalyst (carbonates, described later) cannot gasify to gaseous CO2 under the experimental condition. The O3 concentration from the DBD reactor with IPC configuration was lower than that with PPC configuration or NTP alone (Fig. 4(c, d)). This fact implied that parts of oxygen atoms produced by discharges do not convert to O3 in the DBD reactor with IPC configuration, those oxygen atoms can be adsorbed on the surface of β-MnO2 catalyst. O3 concentrations when the DBD reactors fed with CO at a fixed ED are lower than those when the DBD reactors fed without CO; since β-MnO2 catalyst can decompose O3 to oxygen atoms which react with CO to give CO2 [28,29]. 3.3 Operando drifts-MS analysis 3.3.1 Surface oxygen species at different ED Oxygen species on the catalyst in IPC and PPC configurations were investigated by altering ED using the operando DRIFTS-MS fed with O2/Ar gas mixture. Absorption peaks at 780, 985, 1055, 1113, 1300, and 2120 cm–1 could be found (Figs. 5 (a) and (b)). As summarized in Table S1, the peak at 780 cm–1 is attributed to ionized O3 adsorption M + O3 – [30]. Peaks at 985 and 1113 cm–1 correspond to the adsorption peaks M2+-O2 2– and M + O2 –, respectively [31,32]. Peaks at 1055 and 2120 cm–1 correspond to O3 adsorbed on metal cation (M-O3) and M-OH (M-OHO3), respectively [17,33]. The peak at 1300 cm–1 corresponds to the adsorption of surface atomic oxygen on the surface of the catalyst (MO) [17,34]. The relationship between the peak heights and ED is shown in Fig. 5(c-h). Fig. 5(c) shows that M-OH can adsorb O3 yielding M-OHO3 (Eq. (1)). The peak height of M-OHO3 on the catalyst in PPC configuration is higher than that in IPC configuration, which is due to the high concentration of O3 in PPC configuration (Fig. 5(d)), resulting in a large amount of adsorbed O3. Peak height of δ(OH) (1440 and 1580 cm–1) decreases with increasing ED, this is due to the adsorption of O3 on M-OH [17]. Fig. 5(d) and 5(e) demonstrate that O3 adsorption on the catalyst in PPC configuration is mainly in the form of M-O3 (Eq. (2)), while O3 adsorption on the catalyst in IPC configuration is present in the form of ionized M + O3 – (Eq. (3)). The peak height of MO on the catalyst in IPC configuration is higher than that in PPC configuration at the same ED (Fig. 5(f)), indicating that there is more MO on the surface of the catalyst in the IPC configuration than that in the PPC configuration (Eq. (4)). MO on the catalyst in PPC configuration is mainly formed from O3 decomposition (Eq. (5)) [35]. The significant differences of O3 and O2 adsorption on the catalyst in IPC and PPC configuration are related with M-O3 (only on the catalyst in PPC), M + O3 – and M + O2 – (only on the catalyst in IPC configuration). (1) O 3 + M − OH → M − OH − O 3 (2) O 3 + M → M − O 3 (3) O 3 + M → M + − O 3 − (4) O + M → M = O (5) O 3 + M → M = O + O 2 At the same ED, M2+-O2 2–and M + O2 – peak heights on the catalyst in IPC configuration were higher than that in PPC configuration (Fig. 5(g, h)). M2+-O2 2–and M + O2 – can be produced from O3 reaction on the catalyst in PPC configuration following O3 related reactions. MO combined with O3 in the gas phase to form M2+-O4 2– (Eq. (6)), M2+-O4 2– is not stable and can combine with O3 to form M + O2 – and M + O3 – (Eq. (7)). M + O3 – reacts with O3 to give M2+-O2 2– (Eq. (8)) [17]. Thus, the catalyst of more MO in IPC configuration facilitated the adsorption of O3 and promoted the formation of M2+-O2 2– and M + O2 – (Eqs. (6)-(8)) [36]. (6) M = O + 2 O 3 → M 2 + − O 4 2 − + O 3 (7) M 2 + − O 4 2 − + O 3 → M + − O 2 − + M + − O 3 − + O 2 (8) 3.3.2 Surface oxygen species without CO The changes of surface oxygen species on the catalyst in IPC and PPC configurations at different discharge times are shown in Fig. 6 . Peaks at 780, 985, 1054, 1113, 1300, and 2120 cm–1 have been observed after starting discharge. As the discharge time increases, the peak heights increase to saturated levels (Fig. 6(c) and (f)). After the discharge stops, the peak heights at 1054 (M-OHO3) and 2120 (M-O3) cm–1 decrease to zero (Fig. 6(f)), indicating that the adsorption of O3 on M-OH belongs to weak adsorption (physical adsorption). The peak heights of MO, M + O3 –, M2+-O2 2–, and M + O2 – do not change obviously after the discharge is stopped (Fig. 6(c) and 6(f)), indicating that the adsorption of these oxygen species belongs to chemical adsorption [17]. O3 signals (m/z = 48) from the catalyst in IPC and PPC configurations at different discharge times were shown in Fig. 6(b, e). The O3 MS signal from the catalyst in IPC configuration increases gradually to 4.6 × 10–12 when discharge starts (plasma on) and immediately drops to 3.8 × 10–12 when discharge stops (plasma off) (Fig. 6b). This is due to O3 adsorption on the catalyst, resulting in increase in O3 concentration. When the discharge stops, the O3 MS signal immediately drops to 3.8 × 10–12, indicating that gaseous O3 is generated by discharge. The O3 MS signal from the catalyst in PPC configuration increases immediately to a stable level of 5.4 × 10–12 when the discharge starts (plasma on) (Fig. 6e), this stable level is higher than that in IPC configuration. The lower O3 MS signal from the catalyst in IPC configuration suggested that all O atoms produced by discharges do not convert to O3. Together with the fact that MO on the catalyst in IPC configuration is higher than that in PPC configuration, implying that parts of O atoms absorb on β-MnO2 in IPC configuration forming MO, resulting lower O3 formation [17,35]. 3.3.3 Surface oxygen species with CO The changes of surface oxygen species on the catalyst in IPC and PPC configurations fed with CO/O2/Ar gas mixture at different discharge times are explored in Fig. 7 . Except peaks of MO, M + O3 –, M2+-O2 2–, and M + O2 –, new peaks at 1530, 1630, 1685, 2170, and 2330 cm–1 have been found. The peak at 1530 cm–1 corresponds to monodentate carbonate (vas (CO3 2–)). Peaks at 1630 and 1685 cm–1 correspond to bidentate carbonate (vas (OCO)) [37,38]. The peak at 2170 cm–1 corresponds to gas-phase CO [39] and the peak at 2330 cm–1 corresponds to gas-phase CO2 [40]. Fig. 7(c) and (f) illustrate CO (m/z = 28) and CO2 (m/z = 44) MS signals from the catalyst in IPC and PPC configurations by changing ED. CO MS signal decreases and CO2 MS signal increases simultaneously with increasing ED from 0 to 300 J/L when using the catalyst in IPC configuration (Fig. 7(c)). At 300 J/L, CO2 MS signal in IPC configuration is 1.3 × 10–9, obviously higher than that in PPC configuration (0.6 × 10–9), indicating the CO conversion and CO2 selectivity in IPC configuration are higher than that in PPC configuration. This result is consistent with the results in Fig. 4(a) and (b). The peak heights of surface oxygen species on the catalyst in IPC configuration under condition with or without CO are summarized in Fig. 8 . There is no significant difference in peak heights of M-OHO3 and M-O3 when the catalyst was fed with or without CO Fig. 8(a, b)), indicating that M-OHO3 and M-O3 are basically not involved in CO oxidation. Fig. 8 (c-f) reveals that the peak heights of MO, M + O3 –, M + O2 –, and M2+-O2 2– when the catalyst fed with CO are significantly lower than those when the catalyst fed without CO, indicating that these surface oxygen species relate with CO oxidation following reactions shown in Eqs. (9-12) [17,35]. M + O2 – and M + O3 – contribute the formation of MO and gaseous CO2 (Eqs. (9) and (10)). MO reacts with CO to form monodentate carbonate (Eq. (11)). M2+-O2 2– reacts with CO giving bidentate carbonate (Eq. (12)). (9) M + − O 3 − + 2 CO → M = O + 2 C O 2 (10) M + − O 2 − + CO → M = O + C O 2 (11) M = O + C O 2 → M − O − C O 2 (12) The peak heights of surface oxygen species in PPC configuration under condition with or without CO are shown in Fig. S2. At 300 J/L, the difference between peak heights of M-OHO3 with and without CO is obviously higher than those of MO, M-O3, M + O2 –, M2+-O2 2–, and M + O3 –, suggesting that M-OHO3 played a major role in CO oxidation on the catalyst in PPC configuration. 3.3.4 Behaviors of surface carbonates There are two kinds of carbonates found on β-MnO2 catalyst, monodentate and bidentate carbonates. The peak heights of carbonates on the catalyst in PPC and IPC configuration at different ED are shown in Fig. 9 (a, b). The peak height (5.5 × 10–4 at 300 J/L) of monodentate carbonate (va s(CO3 2–)) on the catalyst in IPC configuration is significantly higher than that (3.0 × 10–4 at 300 J/L) in PPC configuration. However, at a fixed ED, the peak height of bidentate carbonate (vas (OCO)) on the catalyst in IPC configuration is lower than that in PPC configuration. This finding concluded that the catalyst in IPC configuration is benefit to the formation of monodentate carbonate (va s(CO3 2–)), while the catalyst in PPC configuration is advantageous to the formation of bidentate carbonate (vas (OCO)). The relations of peak heights of monodentate and bidentate carbonates on the catalyst in PPC configuration with discharge time are plotted in Fig. 9(d). As the discharge time increased, the peak heights of monodentate carbonate (va s(CO3 2–)) and bidentate carbonate (vas (OCO)) increased. When the discharge time reaches 80 min, the peak heights of vas (CO3 2–) and vas (OCO) tends to stable. After stopping the discharge, the peak height of vas (CO3 2–) immediately drops to 0, while the peak height of vas (OCO) decreases slightly. This result indicated that vas (CO3 2–) is gasified easily to gaseous CO2 (Eq. (13)), while vas (OCO) is difficult to be gasified. (13) M − O − C O 2 → M = O + C O 2 Fig. S3 plots the behaviors of monodentate carbonate (va s(CO3 2–)) and bidentate carbonate (vas (OCO)) on the catalyst in IPC configuration at different temperatures. As the temperature increased, the peak height of vas (OCO) gradually decreased. When the temperature reached 100 °C, the va s(OCO) peak disappeared. This result illustrated that the gasification of vas (OCO) required a temperature near 100 °C [37,41]. Therefore, vas (OCO) was not easy to gasify at room temperature. This fact also explained that the CO2 selectivity on the catalyst in IPC configuration (Fig. 4(b)) was lower than that in IPC configuration, which was due to the formation of vas (OCO). 3.4 Mechanism of CO oxidation In the DBD reactor with IPC configuration, energized electrons impact with O2 resulting in its decomposition to O atom and formation of O3, where O atoms and O3 can adsorb on the catalyst surface, chemically adsorbed O3 can be decomposed to form O atoms in MO (Fig. 10 (a)). CO reacts with MO yielding surface monodentate carbonate, which is easily gasified to gaseous CO2. MO on the catalyst in IPC configuration facilitates the adsorption of O3 and promotes the formation of M2+-O2 2– and M + O2 –, those are important oxygen species that can promote CO oxidation and MO formation. Only the long-life species O3 plays important role in CO oxidation when using the DBD reactor with PPC configuration (Fig. 10(b)). Physically adsorbed O3 reacts with M + O2 – to M2+-O2 2– (Eqs. (6)-(8)), and M2+-O2 2– further reacts with CO to generate bidentate carbonate (Eq. (12)) which is more difficult gasified to gaseous CO2 than monodentate carbonate. 5 Conclusion An operando diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) and mass spectrometry (MS) has been used to investigate CO oxidation on MnO2 catalyst using a reactor in IPC and PPC configurations. The DBD reactor in IPC configuration had higher CO conversion and CO2 selectivity than that in PPC configuration. O atoms generated in the discharge space play important role in CO conversion and CO2 selectivity as they can promote formation of MO on the catalyst in IPC configuration. MO can react with CO to form monodentate carbonate which is easily gasify to gaseous CO2. M + O2 – and M2+-O2 2– on the catalyst in IPC configuration promote CO oxidation and MO formation. O3 can absorb on the catalyst chemically in IPC configuration and physically in PPC configuration. While M-OHO3 on the catalyst in PPC configuration promotes CO oxidation. CO oxidation product on the catalyst in IPC configuration is mainly monodentate carbonate that can gasify to gaseous CO2 even at room temperature. However, CO oxidation product on the catalyst in PPC configuration is mainly bidentate carbonate that is difficult to gasify from MnO2 surface at room temperature. The authors anticipate that the operando DRIFTS-MS method would be useful to investigate the difference between the catalyst in IPC and PPC configurations and to find a satisfied plasma catalysis technology for oxidative removals of harmful CO and organic compounds. coredata.dc:description: The position of the catalyst in a plasma reactor has an important effect on performance of plasma driven catalytic reaction. An operando diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) and mass spectrometry (MS) has been used to investigate CO oxidation on MnO2 catalyst in in-plasma catalysis (IPC) and post-plasma catalysis (PPC) configurations. It was found that the catalyst in IPC configuration has higher CO conversion and CO2 selectivity than that in PPC configuration. Operando DRIFTS-MS analysis showed that the IPC configuration generated more reactive oxygen species (MO) on the catalyst surface than the PPC configuration, where MO, M2+-O2 2–, and M + O2 – are important reactive species promoting CO oxidation to monodentate carbonate that is easy to gasify to gaseous CO2. The physical adsorbed O3 on the catalyst in PPC configuration converts to M2+-O2 2– which combines with CO to form bidentate carbonates that is difficult to gasify to gaseous CO2. The mechanisms of CO oxidation on the catalyst in IPC and PPC configurations are discussed.
coredata.dc:title: Revealing the significant differences of CO plasma oxidation on β-MnO2 catalyst in in- and post-plasma catalysis configurations using operando DRIFTS-MS
